Tech., 13, 1167–1179, https://doi.org/10.5194/amt-13-1167-2020.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode\" codeListValue=\"isCitedBy\"/></gmd:function></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>Release 1 of the Fundamental Climate Data Record (FCDR) of the Meteosat Visible and Infrared Imager (MVIRI) onboard the Meteosat First Generation (MFG)  provides georectified, recalibrated, and consolidated Level 1.5 data of the visible (VIS), infrared (IR) and water vapor (WV) bands along with all metadata, spectral response functions (reconstructed for the VIS channel), as well as calibration information to compute radiance, brightness temperature and reflectance. The VIS band data are provided along with detailed measurement uncertainties and error correlation information. As further elaborated in the Product User Guide, the files are provided in FIDUCEO EASY and FULL (only available on special request) netCDF4 formats.\n\nRelease 1 of the MVIRI FCDR consists of data from the Meteosat-5 satellite with nominal sub-satellite longitude 63 degrees. Release 1 was produced as part of the FP7 ERA-CLIM2 and H2020 FIDUCEO project.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" GMT 1998 / Tue Jan 31 00:12:00 GMT 2006\",\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/MET7FCDR_63degree.png\",\"encodingFormat\":\"netCDF4\",\"description\":\"Release 1 of the Fundamental Climate Data Record (FCDR) of the Meteosat Visible and Infrared Imager (MVIRI) onboard the Meteosat First Generation (MFG)  provides georectified, recalibrated, and consolidated Level 1.5 data of the visible (VIS), infrared (IR) and water vapor (WV) bands along with all metadata, spectral response functions (reconstructed for the VIS channel), as well as calibration information to compute radiance, brightness temperature and reflectance. The VIS band data are provided along with detailed measurement uncertainties and error correlation information. As further elaborated in the Product User Guide, the files are provided in FIDUCEO EASY and FULL (only available on special request) netCDF4 formats.\\r\\n\\r\\nRelease 1 of the MVIRI FCDR consists of data from the Meteosat-5 satellite with nominal sub-satellite longitude 63 degrees. Release 1 was produced as part of the FP7 ERA-CLIM2 and H2020 FIDUCEO project.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0082\",\"name\":\"MVIRI Level 1.5 Climate Data Record Release 1 - MFG - 63 degree\"}" #>  #>  #>  #> $hits$hits[[2]] #> $hits$hits[[2]]$`_index` #> [1] "csw" #>  #> $hits$hits[[2]]$`_type` #> [1] "record" #>  #> $hits$hits[[2]]$`_id` #> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:MSG:MSG15-RSS" #>  #> $hits$hits[[2]]$`_score` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $hits$hits[[2]]$`_source` #> $hits$hits[[2]]$`_source`$abstract #> [1] "Rectified (level 1.5) Meteosat SEVIRI Rapid Scan image data. The baseline scan region is a reduced area of the top 1/3 of a nominal repeat cycle, covering a latitude range from approximately 15 degrees to 70 degrees. The service generates repeat cycles at 5-minute intervals (the same as currently used for weather radars). The dissemination of RSS data is similar to the normal dissemination, with image segments based on 464 lines and compatible with the full disk level 1.5 data scans. Epilogue and prologue (L1.5 Header and L1.5 Trailer) have the same structure. Calibration is as in Full Earth Scan. Image rectification is to 9.5 degreesE. The scans start at 00:00, 00:05, 00:10, 00:15 ... etc. (5 min scan). The differences from the nominal Full Earth scan are that for channels 1 - 11, only segments 6 - 8 are disseminated and for the High Resolution Visible Channel only segments 16 - 24 are disseminated." codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>Rectified (level 1.5) Meteosat SEVIRI Rapid Scan image data. The baseline scan region is a reduced area of the top 1/3 of a nominal repeat cycle, covering a latitude range from approximately 15 degrees to 70 degrees. The service generates repeat cycles at 5-minute intervals (the same as currently used for weather radars). The dissemination of RSS data is similar to the normal dissemination, with image segments based on 464 lines and compatible with the full disk level 1.5 data scans. Epilogue and prologue (L1.5 Header and L1.5 Trailer) have the same structure. Calibration is as in Full Earth Scan. Image rectification is to 9.5 degreesE. The scans start at 00:00, 00:05, 00:10, 00:15 ... etc. (5 min scan). The differences from the nominal Full Earth scan are that for channels 1 - 11, only segments 6 - 8 are disseminated and for the High Resolution Visible Channel only segments 16 - 24 are disseminated.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode 2008 / Wed Mar 16 11:47:43 GMT 2022\",\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/img_msg_rss_onethird_scan.jpg\",\"encodingFormat\":\"Native\",\"description\":\"Rectified (level 1.5) Meteosat SEVIRI Rapid Scan image data. The baseline scan region is a reduced area of the top 1/3 of a nominal repeat cycle, covering a latitude range from approximately 15 degrees to 70 degrees. The service generates repeat cycles at 5-minute intervals (the same as currently used for weather radars). The dissemination of RSS data is similar to the normal dissemination, with image segments based on 464 lines and compatible with the full disk level 1.5 data scans. Epilogue and prologue (L1.5 Header and L1.5 Trailer) have the same structure. Calibration is as in Full Earth Scan. Image rectification is to 9.5 degreesE. The scans start at 00:00, 00:05, 00:10, 00:15 ... etc. (5 min scan). The differences from the nominal Full Earth scan are that for channels 1 - 11, only segments 6 - 8 are disseminated and for the High Resolution Visible Channel only segments 16 - 24 are disseminated.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:MSG:MSG15-RSS\",\"name\":\"Rapid Scan High Rate SEVIRI Level 1.5 Image Data - MSG\"}" #>  #>  #>  #> $hits$hits[[3]] #> $hits$hits[[3]]$`_index` #> [1] "csw" #>  #> $hits$hits[[3]]$`_type` #> [1] "record" #>  #> $hits$hits[[3]]$`_id` #> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:0412" #>  #> $hits$hits[[3]]$`_score` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $hits$hits[[3]]$`_source` #> $hits$hits[[3]]$`_source`$abstract #> [1] "SLSTR SST has a spatial resolution of 1km at nadir. Skin Sea Surface Temperature following the GHRSST L2P GDS2 format specification, see https://www.ghrsst.org/ . \\r\\n\\r\\n- All Sentinel-3 NRT products are available at pick-up point in less than 3h\\r\\n- All Sentinel-3 Non Time Critical (NTC) products are available at pick-up point in less than 30 days.\\r\\nSentinel-3 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0412\",\"name\":\"SLSTR Level 2 Sea Surface Temperature (SST) - Sentinel-3\"}" #>  #>  #>  #> $hits$hits[[4]] #> $hits$hits[[4]]$`_index` #> [1] "csw" #>  #> $hits$hits[[4]]$`_type` #> [1] "record" #>  #> $hits$hits[[4]]$`_id` #> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:METOP:ASCSZR1B" #>  #> $hits$hits[[4]]$`_score` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $hits$hits[[4]]$`_source` #> $hits$hits[[4]]$`_source`$abstract #> [1] "The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. The product is available from the archive in 2 different spatial resolutions; 25 km and 12.5 km. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information. Near real-time distribution discontinued on 29/09/2015 but the product contents are now available in the corresponding Level 2 product 'ASCAT Soil Moisture at 12.5 km Swath Grid'.\r\n\r\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021." #>  #> $hits$hits[[4]]$`_source`$access_constraint #> [1] "copyright" #>  #> $hits$hits[[4]]$`_source`$alternateTitle #> [1] "ASCSZR1B" #>  #> http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. The product is available from the archive in 2 different spatial resolutions; 25 km and 12.5 km. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information. Near real-time distribution discontinued on 29/09/2015 but the product contents are now available in the corresponding Level 2 product 'ASCAT Soil Moisture at 12.5 km Swath Grid'. Metop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021. http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode Operational European codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. The product is available from the archive in 2 different spatial resolutions; 25 km and 12.5 km. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information. Near real-time distribution discontinued on 29/09/2015 but the product contents are now available in the corresponding Level 2 product 'ASCAT Soil Moisture at 12.5 km Swath Grid'.\n\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode 2007 / Thu May 26 08:20:33 GMT 2022\",\"encodingFormat\":\"Native\",\"description\":\"The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. The product is available from the archive in 2 different spatial resolutions; 25 km and 12.5 km. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information. Near real-time distribution discontinued on 29/09/2015 but the product contents are now available in the corresponding Level 2 product 'ASCAT Soil Moisture at 12.5 km Swath Grid'.\\r\\n\\r\\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:METOP:ASCSZR1B\",\"name\":\"ASCAT Level 1 Sigma0 resampled at 12.5 km Swath Grid - Metop - Global\"}" #>  #>  #>  #> $hits$hits[[5]] #> $hits$hits[[5]]$`_index` #> [1] "csw" #>  #> $hits$hits[[5]]$`_type` #> [1] "record" #>  #> $hits$hits[[5]]$`_id` #> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:METOP:ASCSZF1B" #>  #> $hits$hits[[5]]$`_score` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $hits$hits[[5]]$`_source` #> $hits$hits[[5]]$`_source`$abstract #> [1] "The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. This product consists of geo-located radar backscatter values along the six ASCAT beams. The different beam measurements are not collocated into a regular swath grid and the individual measurements are not spatially averaged. The resolution of each of the 255 backscatter values per each beam varies slightly along the beam, but it is approximately 10km (in the along beam direction) x 25 km (across the beam). This product is usually referred to as 'ASCAT Level 1B Full resolution product'. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information.\r\n\r\n\r\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021." #>  #> codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. This product consists of geo-located radar backscatter values along the six ASCAT beams. The different beam measurements are not collocated into a regular swath grid and the individual measurements are not spatially averaged. The resolution of each of the 255 backscatter values per each beam varies slightly along the beam, but it is approximately 10km (in the along beam direction) x 25 km (across the beam). This product is usually referred to as 'ASCAT Level 1B Full resolution product'. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information.\n\n\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" 2007 / Thu May 26 08:20:33 GMT 2022\",\"encodingFormat\":\"Native\",\"description\":\"The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. This product consists of geo-located radar backscatter values along the six ASCAT beams. The different beam measurements are not collocated into a regular swath grid and the individual measurements are not spatially averaged. The resolution of each of the 255 backscatter values per each beam varies slightly along the beam, but it is approximately 10km (in the along beam direction) x 25 km (across the beam). This product is usually referred to as 'ASCAT Level 1B Full resolution product'. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information.\\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:METOP:ASCSZF1B\",\"name\":\"ASCAT Level 1 Sigma0 Full Resolution - Metop - Global\"}" #>  #>  #>  #> $hits$hits[[6]] #> $hits$hits[[6]]$`_index` #> [1] "csw" #>  #> $hits$hits[[6]]$`_type` #> [1] "record" #>  #> $hits$hits[[6]]$`_id` #> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:0241" #>  #> $hits$hits[[6]]$`_score` #> [1] 1 #>  #> $hits$hits[[6]]$`_source` #> $hits$hits[[6]]$`_source`$abstract #> [1] "This is a reprocessed dataset at baseline F06, which is continued by the NRT/NTC data stream from 29/April/2022 onwards.\r\n\r\nAMR-C Level 2 Products as generated by the AMR-C CFI Processor.\r\n\r\nThese products include antenna and brightness temperatures, wet tropospheric correction, water vapour content, and a rain flag. \r\n\r\nSentinel-6 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme. F06, which is continued by the NRT/NTC data stream from 29/April/2022 onwards.\n\nAMR-C Level 2 Products as generated by the AMR-C CFI Processor.\n\nThese products include antenna and brightness temperatures, wet tropospheric correction, water vapour content, and a rain flag. \n\nSentinel-6 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme. It is a collaborative Copernicus mission, implemented and co-funded by the European Commission, ESA, EUMETSAT and the USA, through NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" It includes geo-located, and fully calibrated pulse-limited low-resolution Ku-band and C-band waveforms.\r\n\r\nThis product is most relevant to geophysical retrieval algorithm developers (over ocean, land and ice surfaces), surface characterisations studies (e.g. impact of sea state bias, wave directional effects etc) and Quality Control systems.\r\n\r\nSentinel-6 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme. The Level-1B LR product is output of the LR processor. It includes geo-located, and fully calibrated pulse-limited low-resolution Ku-band and C-band waveforms. This product is most relevant to geophysical retrieval algorithm developers (over ocean, land and ice surfaces), surface characterisations studies (e.g. impact of sea state bias, wave directional effects etc) and Quality Control systems. Sentinel-6 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme. codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>This is a reprocessed dataset at baseline F06, which is continued by the NRT/NTC data stream from 29/April/2022 onwards.\n\nThe Level-1B LR product is output of the LR processor. It includes geo-located, and fully calibrated pulse-limited low-resolution Ku-band and C-band waveforms.\n\nThis product is most relevant to geophysical retrieval algorithm developers (over ocean, land and ice surfaces), surface characterisations studies (e.g. impact of sea state bias, wave directional effects etc) and Quality Control systems.\n\nSentinel-6 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme. It is a collaborative Copernicus mission, implemented and co-funded by the European Commission, ESA, EUMETSAT and the USA, through NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author SRAL Level 1B: Complex echoes (In-phase (I) and Quadrature (Q)) for the Low Resolution Mode (LRM) and/or Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) mode both for C Band and Ku band. When the altimeter is in SAR mode, this product also contains the so-called Pseudo LRM (PLRM) echoes. Sentinel-3 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme. This collection contains reprocessed data from baseline collection 004. (I) and Quadrature (Q)) for the Low Resolution Mode (LRM) and/or Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) mode both for C Band and Ku band. When the altimeter is in SAR mode, this product also contains the so-called Pseudo LRM (PLRM) echoes. Sentinel-3 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme.\n\nThis collection contains reprocessed data from baseline collection 004. Operational data can be found in the corresponding collection.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode (HIRS) operates at 20 channels (19 channels in the infrared and one in the visible). Its main purpose is to provide input for the vertical temperature and humidity profile retrievals. In addition, the HIRS pixel resolution serves as the standard grid resolution for all ATOVS level 2 products.\n\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to The data is transmitted as High Rate transmissions in 12 spectral channels. Level 1.5 image data corresponds to the geolocated and radiometrically pre-processed image data, ready for further processing, e.g. the extraction of meteorological products. Any spacecraft specific effects have been removed, and in particular, linearisation and equalisation of the image radiometry has been performed for all SEVIRI channels. The on-board blackbody data has been processed. Both radiometric and geometric quality control information is included." #>  #> $hits$hits[[10]]$`_source`$access_constraint #> [1] "otherRestrictions" #>  #> $hits$hits[[10]]$`_source`$alternateTitle The data is transmitted as High Rate transmissions in 12 spectral channels. Level 1.5 image data corresponds to the geolocated and radiometrically pre-processed image data, ready for further processing, e.g. the extraction of meteorological products. Any spacecraft specific effects have been removed, and in particular, linearisation and equalisation of the image radiometry has been performed for all SEVIRI channels. The on-board blackbody data has been processed. Both radiometric and geometric quality control information is included. http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode Operational European 2004 / Thu Dec 08 14:07:57 GMT 2022\",\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/msg-level-1-5.jpg\",\"encodingFormat\":\"GeoTIFF\",\"description\":\"Rectified (level 1.5) Meteosat SEVIRI image data. The data is transmitted as High Rate transmissions in 12 spectral channels. Level 1.5 image data corresponds to the geolocated and radiometrically pre-processed image data, ready for further processing, e.g. the extraction of meteorological products. Any spacecraft specific effects have been removed, and in particular, linearisation and equalisation of the image radiometry has been performed for all SEVIRI channels. The on-board blackbody data has been processed. Both radiometric and geometric quality control information is included.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0160\",\"name\":\"High Rate SEVIRI WV6.2 μm Image - MSG - 0 degree \"}" #>  #>  #>  #>  #>  discover(hits_only = TRUE) #> [[1]] #> [[1]]$`_index` #> [1] "csw" #>  #> [[1]]$`_type` #> [1] "record" #>  #> [[1]]$`_id` #> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:0082" #>  #> [[1]]$`_score` #> [1] 1 #>  #> [[1]]$`_source` #> [[1]]$`_source`$abstract #> [1] "Release 1 of the Fundamental Climate Data Record (FCDR) of the Meteosat Visible and Infrared Imager (MVIRI) onboard the Meteosat First Generation (MFG)  provides georectified, recalibrated, and consolidated Level 1.5 data of the visible (VIS), infrared (IR) and water vapor (WV) bands along with all metadata, spectral response functions (reconstructed for the VIS channel), as well as calibration information to compute radiance, brightness temperature and reflectance. The VIS band data are provided along with detailed measurement uncertainties and error correlation information. As further elaborated in the Product User Guide, the files are provided in FIDUCEO EASY and FULL (only available on special request) netCDF4 formats.\r\n\r\nRelease 1 of the MVIRI FCDR consists of data from the Meteosat-5 satellite with nominal sub-satellite longitude 63 degrees. Release 1 was produced as part of the FP7 ERA-CLIM2 and H2020 FIDUCEO project." #>  #> [[1]]$`_source`$access_constraint #> [1] "copyright" #>  #> [[1]]$`_source`$alternateTitle #> [1] "MTP15FIDE0100" Tech., 13, 1167–1179, https://doi.org/10.5194/amt-13-1167-2020. http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode isCitedBy http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author Release 1 of the Fundamental Climate Data Record (FCDR) of the Meteosat Visible and Infrared Imager (MVIRI) onboard the Meteosat First Generation (MFG) provides georectified, recalibrated, and consolidated Level 1.5 data of the visible (VIS), infrared (IR) and water vapor (WV) bands along with all metadata, spectral response functions (reconstructed for the VIS channel), as well as calibration information to compute radiance, brightness temperature and reflectance. The VIS band data are provided along with detailed measurement uncertainties and error correlation information. As further elaborated in the Product User Guide, the files are provided in FIDUCEO EASY and FULL (only available on special request) netCDF4 formats. Release 1 of the MVIRI FCDR consists of data from the Meteosat-5 satellite with nominal sub-satellite longitude 63 degrees. Tech., 13, 1167–1179, https://doi.org/10.5194/amt-13-1167-2020.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode\" codeListValue=\"isCitedBy\"/></gmd:function></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>Release 1 of the Fundamental Climate Data Record (FCDR) of the Meteosat Visible and Infrared Imager (MVIRI) onboard the Meteosat First Generation (MFG)  provides georectified, recalibrated, and consolidated Level 1.5 data of the visible (VIS), infrared (IR) and water vapor (WV) bands along with all metadata, spectral response functions (reconstructed for the VIS channel), as well as calibration information to compute radiance, brightness temperature and reflectance. The VIS band data are provided along with detailed measurement uncertainties and error correlation information. As further elaborated in the Product User Guide, the files are provided in FIDUCEO EASY and FULL (only available on special request) netCDF4 formats.\n\nRelease 1 of the MVIRI FCDR consists of data from the Meteosat-5 satellite with nominal sub-satellite longitude 63 degrees. Release 1 was produced as part of the FP7 ERA-CLIM2 and H2020 FIDUCEO project.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode GMT 1998 / Tue Jan 31 00:12:00 GMT 2006\",\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/MET7FCDR_63degree.png\",\"encodingFormat\":\"netCDF4\",\"description\":\"Release 1 of the Fundamental Climate Data Record (FCDR) of the Meteosat Visible and Infrared Imager (MVIRI) onboard the Meteosat First Generation (MFG)  provides georectified, recalibrated, and consolidated Level 1.5 data of the visible (VIS), infrared (IR) and water vapor (WV) bands along with all metadata, spectral response functions (reconstructed for the VIS channel), as well as calibration information to compute radiance, brightness temperature and reflectance. The VIS band data are provided along with detailed measurement uncertainties and error correlation information. As further elaborated in the Product User Guide, the files are provided in FIDUCEO EASY and FULL (only available on special request) netCDF4 formats.\\r\\n\\r\\nRelease 1 of the MVIRI FCDR consists of data from the Meteosat-5 satellite with nominal sub-satellite longitude 63 degrees. Release 1 was produced as part of the FP7 ERA-CLIM2 and H2020 FIDUCEO project.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0082\",\"name\":\"MVIRI Level 1.5 Climate Data Record Release 1 - MFG - 63 degree\"}" #>  #>  #>  #> [[2]] #> [[2]]$`_index` #> [1] "csw" #>  #> [[2]]$`_type` #> [1] "record" #>  #> [[2]]$`_id` #> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:MSG:MSG15-RSS" #>  #> [[2]]$`_score` #> [1] 1 #>  #> [[2]]$`_source` #> [[2]]$`_source`$abstract #> [1] "Rectified (level 1.5) Meteosat SEVIRI Rapid Scan image data. The baseline scan region is a reduced area of the top 1/3 of a nominal repeat cycle, covering a latitude range from approximately 15 degrees to 70 degrees. The service generates repeat cycles at 5-minute intervals (the same as currently used for weather radars). The dissemination of RSS data is similar to the normal dissemination, with image segments based on 464 lines and compatible with the full disk level 1.5 data scans. Epilogue and prologue (L1.5 Header and L1.5 Trailer) have the same structure. Calibration is as in Full Earth Scan. Image rectification is to 9.5 degreesE. The scans start at 00:00, 00:05, 00:10, 00:15 ... etc. (5 min scan). The differences from the nominal Full Earth scan are that for channels 1 - 11, only segments 6 - 8 are disseminated and for the High Resolution Visible Channel only segments 16 - 24 are disseminated." http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author Rectified (level 1.5) Meteosat SEVIRI Rapid Scan image data. The baseline scan region is a reduced area of the top 1/3 of a nominal repeat cycle, covering a latitude range from approximately 15 degrees to 70 degrees. The service generates repeat cycles at 5-minute intervals (the same as currently used for weather radars). The dissemination of RSS data is similar to the normal dissemination, with image segments based on 464 lines and compatible with the full disk level 1.5 data scans. Epilogue and prologue (L1.5 Header and L1.5 Trailer) have the same structure. Calibration is as in Full Earth Scan. Image rectification is to 9.5 degreesE. The scans start at 00:00, 00:05, 00:10, 00:15 ... etc. (5 min scan). The differences from the nominal Full Earth scan are that for channels 1 - 11, only segments 6 - 8 are disseminated and for the High Resolution Visible Channel only segments 16 - 24 are disseminated. 2008 / Wed Mar 16 11:47:43 GMT 2022\",\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/img_msg_rss_onethird_scan.jpg\",\"encodingFormat\":\"Native\",\"description\":\"Rectified (level 1.5) Meteosat SEVIRI Rapid Scan image data. The baseline scan region is a reduced area of the top 1/3 of a nominal repeat cycle, covering a latitude range from approximately 15 degrees to 70 degrees. The service generates repeat cycles at 5-minute intervals (the same as currently used for weather radars). The dissemination of RSS data is similar to the normal dissemination, with image segments based on 464 lines and compatible with the full disk level 1.5 data scans. Epilogue and prologue (L1.5 Header and L1.5 Trailer) have the same structure. Calibration is as in Full Earth Scan. Image rectification is to 9.5 degreesE. The scans start at 00:00, 00:05, 00:10, 00:15 ... etc. (5 min scan). The differences from the nominal Full Earth scan are that for channels 1 - 11, only segments 6 - 8 are disseminated and for the High Resolution Visible Channel only segments 16 - 24 are disseminated.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:MSG:MSG15-RSS\",\"name\":\"Rapid Scan High Rate SEVIRI Level 1.5 Image Data - MSG\"}" #>  #>  #>  #> [[3]] #> [[3]]$`_index` #> [1] "csw" #>  #> [[3]]$`_type` #> [1] "record" #>  #> [[3]]$`_id` #> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:0412" #>  #> [[3]]$`_score` #> [1] 1 #>  #> [[3]]$`_source` #> [[3]]$`_source`$abstract #> [1] "SLSTR SST has a spatial resolution of 1km at nadir. Skin Sea Surface Temperature following the GHRSST L2P GDS2 format specification, see https://www.ghrsst.org/ . \\r\\n\\r\\n- All Sentinel-3 NRT products are available at pick-up point in less than 3h\\r\\n- All Sentinel-3 Non Time Critical (NTC) products are available at pick-up point in less than 30 days.\\r\\nSentinel-3 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0412\",\"name\":\"SLSTR Level 2 Sea Surface Temperature (SST) - Sentinel-3\"}" #>  #>  #>  #> [[4]] #> [[4]]$`_index` #> [1] "csw" #>  #> [[4]]$`_type` #> [1] "record" #>  #> [[4]]$`_id` #> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:METOP:ASCSZR1B" #>  #> [[4]]$`_score` #> [1] 1 #>  #> [[4]]$`_source` #> [[4]]$`_source`$abstract #> [1] "The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. The product is available from the archive in 2 different spatial resolutions; 25 km and 12.5 km. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information. Near real-time distribution discontinued on 29/09/2015 but the product contents are now available in the corresponding Level 2 product 'ASCAT Soil Moisture at 12.5 km Swath Grid'.\r\n\r\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021." #>  #> [[4]]$`_source`$access_constraint #> [1] "copyright" #>  #> [[4]]$`_source`$alternateTitle #> [1] "ASCSZR1B" #>  #> http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. The product is available from the archive in 2 different spatial resolutions; 25 km and 12.5 km. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information. Near real-time distribution discontinued on 29/09/2015 but the product contents are now available in the corresponding Level 2 product 'ASCAT Soil Moisture at 12.5 km Swath Grid'. codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. The product is available from the archive in 2 different spatial resolutions; 25 km and 12.5 km. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information. Near real-time distribution discontinued on 29/09/2015 but the product contents are now available in the corresponding Level 2 product 'ASCAT Soil Moisture at 12.5 km Swath Grid'.\n\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. This product consists of geo-located radar backscatter values along the six ASCAT beams. The different beam measurements are not collocated into a regular swath grid and the individual measurements are not spatially averaged. The resolution of each of the 255 backscatter values per each beam varies slightly along the beam, but it is approximately 10km (in the along beam direction) x 25 km (across the beam). This product is usually referred to as 'ASCAT Level 1B Full resolution product'. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information.\r\n\r\n\r\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021." #>  #> http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. This product consists of geo-located radar backscatter values along the six ASCAT beams. The different beam measurements are not collocated into a regular swath grid and the individual measurements are not spatially averaged. The resolution of each of the 255 backscatter values per each beam varies slightly along the beam, but it is approximately 10km (in the along beam direction) x 25 km (across the beam). This product is usually referred to as 'ASCAT Level 1B Full resolution product'. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information. codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. This product consists of geo-located radar backscatter values along the six ASCAT beams. The different beam measurements are not collocated into a regular swath grid and the individual measurements are not spatially averaged. The resolution of each of the 255 backscatter values per each beam varies slightly along the beam, but it is approximately 10km (in the along beam direction) x 25 km (across the beam). This product is usually referred to as 'ASCAT Level 1B Full resolution product'. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information.\n\n\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" 2007 / Thu May 26 08:20:33 GMT 2022\",\"encodingFormat\":\"Native\",\"description\":\"The prime objective of the Advanced SCATterometer (ASCAT) is to measure wind speed and direction over the oceans, and the main operational application is the assimilation of ocean winds in NWP models. Other operational applications, based on the use of measurements of the backscattering coefficient, are sea ice edge detection and monitoring, monitoring sea ice, snow cover, soil moisture and surface parameters. This product consists of geo-located radar backscatter values along the six ASCAT beams. The different beam measurements are not collocated into a regular swath grid and the individual measurements are not spatially averaged. The resolution of each of the 255 backscatter values per each beam varies slightly along the beam, but it is approximately 10km (in the along beam direction) x 25 km (across the beam). This product is usually referred to as 'ASCAT Level 1B Full resolution product'. Note that some of the data are reprocessed. Please refer to the associated product validation reports or product release notes for further information.\\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\nMetop-A data are available in the Data Centre up to 15/11/2021.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:METOP:ASCSZF1B\",\"name\":\"ASCAT Level 1 Sigma0 Full Resolution - Metop - Global\"}" #>  #>  #>  #> [[6]] #> [[6]]$`_index` #> [1] "csw" #>  #> [[6]]$`_type` #> [1] "record" #>  #> [[6]]$`_id` #> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:0241" #>  #> [[6]]$`_score` #> [1] 1 #>  #> [[6]]$`_source` #> [[6]]$`_source`$abstract #> [1] "This is a reprocessed dataset at baseline F06, which is continued by the NRT/NTC data stream from 29/April/2022 onwards.\r\n\r\nAMR-C Level 2 Products as generated by the AMR-C CFI Processor.\r\n\r\nThese products include antenna and brightness temperatures, wet tropospheric correction, water vapour content, and a rain flag. \r\n\r\nSentinel-6 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme. F06, which is continued by the NRT/NTC data stream from 29/April/2022 onwards.\n\nAMR-C Level 2 Products as generated by the AMR-C CFI Processor.\n\nThese products include antenna and brightness temperatures, wet tropospheric correction, water vapour content, and a rain flag. \n\nSentinel-6 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme. It is a collaborative Copernicus mission, implemented and co-funded by the European Commission, ESA, EUMETSAT and the USA, through NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>This is a reprocessed dataset at baseline F06, which is continued by the NRT/NTC data stream from 29/April/2022 onwards.\n\nThe Level-1B LR product is output of the LR processor. It includes geo-located, and fully calibrated pulse-limited low-resolution Ku-band and C-band waveforms.\n\nThis product is most relevant to geophysical retrieval algorithm developers (over ocean, land and ice surfaces), surface characterisations studies (e.g. impact of sea state bias, wave directional effects etc) and Quality Control systems.\n\nSentinel-6 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme. It is a collaborative Copernicus mission, implemented and co-funded by the European Commission, ESA, EUMETSAT and the USA, through NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" It includes geo-located, and fully calibrated pulse-limited low-resolution Ku-band and C-band waveforms.\\r\\n\\r\\nThis product is most relevant to geophysical retrieval algorithm developers (over ocean, land and ice surfaces), surface characterisations studies (e.g. impact of sea state bias, wave directional effects etc) and Quality Control systems.\\r\\n\\r\\nSentinel-6 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme. codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>SRAL Level 1B: Complex echoes (In-phase (I) and Quadrature (Q)) for the Low Resolution Mode (LRM) and/or Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) mode both for C Band and Ku band. When the altimeter is in SAR mode, this product also contains the so-called Pseudo LRM (PLRM) echoes. Sentinel-3 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme.\n\nThis collection contains reprocessed data from baseline collection 004. The data is transmitted as High Rate transmissions in 12 spectral channels. Level 1.5 image data corresponds to the geolocated and radiometrically pre-processed image data, ready for further processing, e.g. the extraction of meteorological products. Any spacecraft specific effects have been removed, and in particular, linearisation and equalisation of the image radiometry has been performed for all SEVIRI channels. The on-board blackbody data has been processed. Both radiometric and geometric quality control information is included." #>  #> [[10]]$`_source`$access_constraint #> [1] "otherRestrictions" #>  #> [[10]]$`_source`$alternateTitle #> codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>Rectified (level 1.5) Meteosat SEVIRI image data. The data is transmitted as High Rate transmissions in 12 spectral channels. Level 1.5 image data corresponds to the geolocated and radiometrically pre-processed image data, ready for further processing, e.g. the extraction of meteorological products. Any spacecraft specific effects have been removed, and in particular, linearisation and equalisation of the image radiometry has been performed for all SEVIRI channels. The on-board blackbody data has been processed. Both radiometric and geometric quality control information is included.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode
